One of the fundamental debates in ethics is between [[cognitivism (ethics)|cognitivists]] and [[non-cognitivism|non-cognitivists]]. Their debate is over the truth-aptitude of ethical propositions. Ethical propositions are those used to either positively or negatively morally evaluate something. Concepts of value, e.g. good and evil, or concepts of [[deontic logic|deontic modality]], e.g. obligation ("should/ought") and prohibition ("should not/ought not"), or similar concepts of other kinds (e.g. fairness and unfairness), are typically components of ethical propositions. Here are some examples:
    −
* "Sally is a good person."
+
* "Sally is a bad stupid person."
 
* "People should not steal."
 
* "People should not steal."
 
* "The [[OJ Simpson|Simpson]] verdict was unjust."
 
* "The [[OJ Simpson|Simpson]] verdict was unjust."
